body: LGTM

Seems like a bad idea to have database_name in two places. There are many scenarios where they might get out-of-sync. I'm surprised the object is detached at that point, but if it's the case you should emit a query and get an attached object and modify it.
Either forking it or using some equivalent component that is maintained.
thriftpy isn't py3 compatible yet I think

It doesn't seem like the client would change the speed of the query that is executing on the server. Do you have data on the difference? Can you run the query a few times on both sides and see what the average is?
Note that the URLs are stateful so if someone bookmarks a filtered dash it captures the filter.
@mistercrunch it does, https://travis-ci.org/eleme/thriftpy
I have the same problem with version 0.17.5, python 3.6.1. How can I help to reproduce it?
That is handy, but it requires that they always access the page via bookmark.  If someone is jumping between dashboards within the UI it doesn't solve the problem.
LGTM. Congrats on your first Superset PR @justinpark !
@ascott merging this on your behalf so that it can make the next release!
It's not clear to me that users would expect a sticky filter that would go beyond the browser session. I doubt other tools like Tableau would do this.
The issue is resolved.

Yes, that's a good point. But I'm not sure what you mean by getting an attached object and modify. The object is already deleted when it reaches post_deletion. Another way I think I can do is overwriting the delete function instead of the post_delete so the object is not detached. And having all related permissions removed in delete function. Sounds good to you? @mistercrunch

I would be open to working on this, if this has not been done. I'm familiar with Python and am using superset at my company internally to display various information from redshift (But would like to move us to BQ)

For reference, the way that this is done for `table.js` is by leveraging the metric's `d3format` configuration through the `slice.d3format` method.

You can imagine that people using pivot table may want different format for different metrics. 

The longer term solution for this is in a branch on my repo `mistercrunch/metrics` where there's a new intricate control introduced for metrics, where people would define metrics in the explore view as either an expression, agg function/column, or by referencing a predefined metric in a popover, all of that in a popover that also allows labeling of the metric and formatting.
We may want to merge that in the meantime, it would work for pivoting a single metric or many metrics where the same formatting applies.
I see. Thank you so much for the insight!
Please define crash and define big.
@xrmx who can i find the config
@qinzl1 i mean to define in plain english. What is a crash for you? Where does it happen?How much data is big?

@mistercrunch fork & update in progress ([link here](https://github.com/dennybiasiolli/react-alert/tree/updating_deps)).
I'm also trying to contact the author in order to unlock the "no maintenance intended" status
I faced same issue like above.

For you to be able to maintain the package you'll need access to push releases to `npm`, hopefully the author can grant you that. The main repo is where the work (PRs, issues, ...) should be done, so either you move his repo to your GH org or he grants you admin rights.
Yes thanks, I'm waiting for a response from @schiehll, the author of the component, in order to have admin rights on the repo or at least on `npm` package
Still occurs in 17.6, I'm guessing that nobody actually uses the REST api for this sort of thing. I guess I'll see what my other options are to automate creating tables.
I'm opting to write to the sqllite database directly.
+1 same issue here.

Update: the author is working on a v2 of `react-alert` component, with updated code and dependency. The new version should be compatible with the latest react version without warnings.
As soon as it's released I can test the new version and eventually open a new PR updating the component dependency.
This PR should help https://github.com/airbnb/superset/pull/2709
Rebased to current master, and reformatted to satisfy codeclimate! Any possibility of a re-review/merge @mistercrunch or @ascott ?
LGTM. Thanks for bearing with us through many major rebase.
Sometimes we miss notifications feel free to ping asking for review as often as every other day!
Awesome. Grateful that you are taking this on!

you can lower `ROW_LIMIT` in your `superset_config.py`

@joshuacano I'd be happy helping you out while working on this. I see you are in SF and we love to host at Airbnb so we could host you for coding sessions or for a few days while you crank that out.

I can also help improving and clarifying the connector interface while working on this so that it's more straightforward to add the next connectors.

Wondering if there's a package (or an api) who has the geojsons so we don't have to add them one by one.

@joshwalters @mistercrunch thats great, i tried to tackle this issue on my own, but i believe having a spark connector instead of a bigquery is a much neater solution, since you can connect spark to bigquery and much more, hadoop or elastic search.
@Bamieh , what do you use to connect spark to big query?
There shouldn't be a default. Similarly to the `BROKER_URL` it should be a well-documented parameter, but no defaults make sense and will only cause more trouble.

FileSystemCache shouldn't be made default as that will save data locally. That's not only a bad practice (for sysadmins and developers trying to scale it horizontally), but it will also hide the fact you need to configure results backend to anything that Celery supports. 

I think this parameter should be just properly documented and present in the sample configuration file - just like the `BROKER_URL`.

Since Celery supports Redis as a backend, then @wyndhblb example should work perfectly fine. But it doesn't, and I have an exact same problem, not sure why.

I had the same issue on 0.17.5 with Python 2.7.
I changed the `Origin` field in the Time section of the Filter Box slice to nothing (it was set to `default` before) and that seemed to have fixed it for now

Edit: It broke again after changing one of the dimensions in filter control so this was no proper fix.
Edit2: If that wasnt clear the `Couldn't parse date string [[u'1', u' ', u'h', u'o', u'u', u'r', u' ', u'a', u'g', u'o']]` is saying it can't parse `1 hour ago`

Looks like there is a conflict: `superset/__init__.py` defines `results_backend` and there is also `superset/results_backend.py` file. Separately to that, the error message refers to the `RESULTS_BACKEND` from the global scope that the superset is using internally, rather than to the one from Celery. So changing the value in `CeleryConfig` won't make a difference. Looks like a bigger change is needed here.
I am facing the same issue as @desavera . Initially the Python `NoneType is not iterable` exception pops up, then the query starts running and hangs forever. Looks like a SQLLab connection issue.
Same issue as well.  Options listed, but only sorts by main metric.
You can skip the BUG momentously by only selecting the datasource from the menu and then typing explicit queries on the editor !
On which database engine is that happening on? Also please provide the full error stack trace from the web server logs.
Also would be nice if you can confirm that this is still an issue on 0.17.6
choose explore the slice and change the time column to ds2

The sorting applies to the "Series Limit", not to the sorting of the legend or the stack itself. An example of that is if you wanted to plot the `% of rural population` for the top 10 most populated countries.
Good catch. I'm not sure why it's not a problem on our end. But upon looking I think we don't need the `results_backend` module anymore.
https://github.com/airbnb/superset/pull/2717

This feature is part of FAB (Flask-AppBuilder), which in turn rely on Flask-WTF, and WTFForms.

As far as I discovered, those environment variable names were changed and not sync anymore by the time of writing this.

Adding this to config.py will disable CSRF, which does not work ever.
```
WTF_CSRF_ENABLED = False
```
I don't know if package or api exist. I can create this but i don't know if it's good idea because, if user don't have network, user will don't have tools.
I have a PR with better documentation coming

@timfeirg sorry, typo :) i meant `?charset=utf8` without the `mb4`

Hi! Do you know when will this change be commited into the master branch?
Thanks!

I'm sorry, I just tried both `?charset=utf8` and `?charset=utf8mb4` using superset under python3.6.1, and open up the example charts provided by superset, for example `/superset/dashboard/misc_charts/`, and the request ended up with the same `UnicodeDecodeError` as described in this issue.

If I switch back to python2.7, the example charts would work fine, with or without adding the extra `charset` configs.

[this comment](https://github.com/airbnb/superset/issues/2600#issuecomment-299905182) was a mistake, @xrmx

I'm not against breaking down `views/core.py` as it has grown to be a pretty big module, but I'd like to follow a different approach.

I don't like putting logic in `__init__.py` files. I think they should generally be used only for defining how packages should be exposed (show or hiding modules, lifting classes from module up to package level, ...)

Another approach to breaking things down could be around getting all the model views our of `core.py` and into `model_views.py`

Thanks for review. I agree that `__init__.py` should be used for exposing purpose.

Moving to model_views.py does not make much differrence on visibility.

How about moving to another file in subfolders and use `__init__.py` to expose those?

EDIT: CI is broken, I will fix and reopen this later.

@Sarrae1406 I am working on workaround for this issue.

My use case is I want to make dashboard available to anyone with secured URL.
1. I added the permissions required to Public role, which is can dashboard on Superset.
2. I bypass the security check at particular endpoint so that whenever it receives and verifies a hash from frontend, it bypass the check and vice versa.
python version? db backend? connection string flags?

I mean you could break down `core.py` into different subsets of views. Would be:
* explore.py
* dashboard.py
* sql_lab.py
* maybe `core.py` becomes `common.py`
* and maybe datasource_editor.py, though I think that belongs in the `connectors` package for the most part

Though this kind of PR creates annoying merge conflicts. Either we try to merge as much as possible beforehand, bite the bullet and do it, or wait later on until it's more needed.

Also note that another approach would be to structure the apps more as blueprints where the first breakdown would be explore, dashboard and sql_lab, and each one of these package (flask blueprint) would have their own views.py / models.py / templates.

I'm not sure if it's worth it at this time though.
Given the merge conflicts and long time not addressed requested changes I'm going to close this. Please reopen with the proposed approach and a successful build

This would be as a new visualization of the `nvd3.js`. The x axis might be either a numeric column that must be "grouped by", or a metric that is an aggregate function. We may need a new control that represents a superset of columns and metrics for that purpose.

Options are currently sorted by the metric in a descending fashion. Users have been asking for selectors that are simply alphabetical. 

We could also bring in filters that are not based on a metric at all (simply a DISTINCT list) but that would be slightly harder for a set of reasons. It may be easier for the user to provide a dummy metric.

Ideally each filter could have a different sorting rule, where ideally you'd add and configure the filters individually, pick whether that filter is based on a metric and which metric, and then the sort order (asc, desc, alphaetical). This control would behave a bit like the `Filters` control where you handle a list of N elements that are configured individually.

@graceguo-supercat

I'm pretty sure I recently fixed this on `master`. It happened when a datasource behind a Slice on a dash was deleted. Please confirm that it's fixed on master. Hopefully I can get a release out this week.
There was a transient travis issue, I restarted the build and it worked. Merging now. Thanks for the PR!
